newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Swiss move to tighten money laundering rules.
newsitem.headline: Swiss move to tighten money laundering rules.

text.p: The upper house of the Swiss parliament has approved a tightening of money laundering laws giving bankers a duty -- and not just a right -- to report financial transactions they suspect are tied to illegal drugs trade or other Mafia-style crimes.
"Up to now there was no obligation to report suspicious transactions, only a right to report," a finance ministry official said.

The upper house late on Monday approved a proposal from the lower house with minor changes. The draft has now been returned to the lower house to iron out the differences and final passage is expected shortly.
"There is no substantial difference between the two proposals," the official said.

The new law conforms to international standards and marks another step in Switzerland's attempt to rid itself of the reputation for being a haven for the money laundering activities of corrupt politicians, dictators and drug smugglers.
In 1990 Switzerland outlawed money laundering and in 1994 it gave bankers the right to breach the country's legendary banking secrecy laws and report suspicious transactions to authorities.
Under the new law, bankers who do not report suspicious transactions can face fines up to 200,000 Swiss francs ($138,000).
The law has also been broadened in its scope and now covers all areas of the financial sector, such as banks, life insurers, investment funds and securities firms.
The law also gives the police the power to freeze suspicious assets pending an investigation, and requires that money managers keep a paper trail on financial transactions.
One of the issues under debate is the difference between negligent and deliberate behaviour by bankers.
The lower house's proposal did not distinguish between bankers being negligent in their reporting and bankers deliberately not reporting suspicious transactions.
Finance minister Kaspar Villiger fears a flood of insignificant reports from fearful bank employees if negligence can be fined, Swiss News Agency (SDA) said.
